subject: Gardening
title: Plants That See Light
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Plants That See Light.

hook.text: Plants don't have eyes, but they detect light direction, intensity, and even color. They see in their own way.

buildup.text: Photoreceptor proteins in plant cells respond to different wavelengthsâ€”red, blue, and far-red light.

discovery.text: Phytochrome sensors tell plants whether they're in sunlight or shade by measuring the red-to-far-red ratio.

twist.text: A shaded plant detects reflected far-red light from neighbors and grows taller to escapeâ€”before being shaded.

climax.text: Plants have at least 11 types of photoreceptors. Humans have 4. Plants are better at seeing light than we are.

punchline.text: Plants have more light sensors than human eyes do.

quiz.question: How do plants detect whether they are in shade or sunlight?
options: Using phytochrome sensors that detect the red-to-far-red light ratio
By sensing wind patterns that differ in open vs. shaded areas
